title: EVIDENCE PRESENTED
text:
III. EVIDENCE PRESENTED
Testimony of Baird Brown
Baird Brown developed a successfu l plaintiff's personal injury law practice, specializing in
mass tort litigation. Prior to 2019, he began to display symptoms of Parkinson's disease and in

December 2019 and January 2020, Brown was frequently absent from the Brown Law offices
due to extreme back pain which necessitated spinal surgery in December 2019, followed by
recovery and recuperation well into 2020. (Id., 161:6 -162: 12.) The Covid-19 lockdown
required Brown to reduce his exposure to the pandemic by working from his home office,
starting in March 2020 and continuing until at least March 2023. (Id., 162:24-163:23.) Brown
suffered a near-fatal infection of Covid-19 in January 2022, causing complete respiratory failure
which required a ventilator to breathe for him in the Torrance Hospital ICU. (Id., p.164: 10-
166: 16.) In-patient and out-patient treatment s following this serious illness extended into mid-
2022. (Id., 166: 17-26.)
In addition to these health issues, after a lengthy investigation by the California Bar
Association, Brown was formally suspended by the California Supreme Court, effective April 1,
2020, for a period of three months, pursuant to disciplinary proceeding s. (Def. Ex. 15503.) He
had been facing a one-year suspension. In compliance with Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule
9.20, he submitted a signed declaration under penalty of perjury affirming that he notified all
clients and urged them to seek alternative counsel (Def. Ex. 15508; RT 1/27/25, Brown Cross,
48: 1-50:24.) He acknowledged in his own testimony that he signed this declaration, which was
executed on May 7, 2020. (RT 1/27/25, p. 49:24-51:6.)
During the Covid "lockdown, " plaintiff worked at home but communicated regularly, he
claims, with Pak and staff in his office. (l/23/25 at 25, ln. 9 to 19.) After the lockdown, he
admitted that he stopped going into the office, except occasiona lly on weekends. (RT 1 /23/25 at
p. 25:20 -27.)
Plaintiffs contend that despite these health crises and his suspension, Brown had no intention
to retire and continued to maintain his practice and go into work on weekend s to review matters
until June 2023, when he first had suspicions that Michelle Pak, his office manager, was no
longer working for him and that something was amiss with his cases. (RT 1/22/25 p. 119: 19 -
122: 28.) It was only upon further inquiry after that date that Brown claims he learned for the
first time that his cases had been transferred to another law firm, the law offices of Donald G.
Norris, and that his office manager, defendant Pak, was no longer working for him, but for
Norris. Norris and Pak contend that Brown transferred his mass tort practice to Norris when
Brown realized that his declining health and the suspension made it impossible to continue to
practice law and that Brown participated in and consented to the transfer.
Plaintiff s cognitive decline was on display at trial. While he could understand questions
and speak clearly and eloquently at times, he appeared to have little memory of past events and
became easily confused and exhausted on the witness stand. He had little to no recollection of
what had occurred with his firm or his cases and clients for the entire relevant time period (2019
to 2023). Indeed, at times he contradicted his attorney and wife's theory of the case by stating
that he knew Norris would take responsibility for all of his cases. (RT 1/27 /25 am, p. 26: 18-21.)
The court received testimony from Dr. Matthew Lombard, Brown's treating physician for the;
past four or five years, who testified that Brown suffers from Parkinson's disease and some
memory issues associated with it but has not been diagnosed with dementia. (RT 1/22/25, 84:9-
85:9; 88: 10-11.) Or. Lombard conceded that Brown could suffer from dementia even though he
has no formal diagnosis, and that if it reached an advanced stage, he could forget meeting

it was only in an early stage. (Id., at 90:6-12.) Dr. Lombard, however, admitted that he himself
had no memory of his patient's health situation in the critical time period, 2019 to 2_020, and.
testified that he saw him only rarely. Or. Lombard' s testimony was further undermined by his
utter lack of familiarity with his own patient's chart: for example, he indicated that Brown had
had no significant health history, apparently not knowing about the many months in critical care,
the lengthy hospitalization and extended rehab due to Covid in 2022, including extended time on
a respirator, as well as plaintiff s multiple back surgeries. (Id., at p. 87: 16-88:28.) The court
finds that Dr. Lombard is either insufficientl y familiar with his patients' records or mistaken if he
believes Brown is only showing mild cognitive decline; Mr. Brown displayed significant
cognitive impairment while testifying.
Mrs. Brown testified that while she observed some signs of Parkinson's-related
motor symptoms in 2019, Mr. Brown's cognition remained steady and did not significantly
decline until late 2022, following his "near death" experience with Covid-19, sometime mid-
2022. (RT 3/5/25, p. 188, In. 12-16; RT 3/13/25, p. 129:17-131:20.) Although she then changed
her testimony somewhat and said that she did not notice a cognitive impairment until sometime
in 2023 (RT 3/5/25, p. 188-189), she later reaffirmed that her husband began to be cognitively
impaired in 2022. (RT 3/13/25 at p. 130: 5-24.)
Given this testimony (and that of the three legal assistants--Granillo, Navarro and Robinson-Â­
discussed below), the court conclude s that plaintiff was beginnin g to show many symptoms of
Parkinson 's in 2019 and before, but that he continued to present as a cognitively functionin g
individual and was able to conduct routine legal business through at least 2020, as demonstrated
by the various documents he was drafting in that period. By the second day of his testimony at
trial, it appeared to the court that he had very little recollection of the events that occurred in
2019 through 2023. For example, he could not even recall whether he "practiced law" in 2021,
2022 or 2023, the years in which his lawyers contend he was still able to practice but had his
clients stolen from him. (RT 1/23/25, p. 42:2-12.) Accordingly, the court could give little
weight to his testimony, except where it was corroborated by other testimony or evidence.
Brown testified that he recognized the lease to the suite of offices he rented in 2019 on
Wilshire Blvd.. He claims he never agreed that Norris could take over the lease or become a
subtenant, which would have required written authorization from the landlord based on the
written terms of the lease. (RT 1/22/25, p. 95:18-98: 28, and Exh. 19.) He also explained that he
never said Norris could use his law firm's personnel. (Id., at 103:15 -21.) But later, somewhat
inconsistently, he testified that he told Norris that Norris could use Brown's rented offices for
Norris's law practice "several years into the lease term. " (Id., at 103:1-20.)
At trial Brown claimed that he had no knowledge of any deal to transfer his cases to
Norris. He claims Pak never told him that her agreement with the Baird firm had terminated.
(RT 1/22/25, p. 101:2-7.) He denies ever having a meeting with Pak and Norris to discuss
transfer of cases to Norris. (Id., at 102: 23-27.) He never agreed to transfer the "bulk of his"
cases to Norris. (Id., at 102:28-103: l 0.) He never told anyone that Norris was a litigator with
his firm, nor did he authorize anyone to tell third parties that Norris was a litigator with his firm.
(Id., at p. 105:2-16.) When shown Exhibit 1379, he testified that he did not authorize anyone to
send this letter but then conceded that the signature at the bottom could be his own. He claimed
to have no recollection of the letter. (Id., at p. 105:26-p. 107:15, and Exh. 1379.) He denies I 4

comes up with [the client's] case" during his three months suspension. (Exh. 1638, 1/22/25, pp.
110:3-113:9.) While he claims he had no knowledge that Pak was going to be working for.
Norris as his office manager in the April 2020 time frame, he admitted that Pak had shown him
the draft of an agreement she and Norris were drawing up in the July 2019 time frame. (1/22/25
at 113:10-114:28.)1
The court also received into evidence Exhibit 1573, a series of text messages between
Brown and Pak. Tellingly, on April 26, 2020, Pak and Norris have an exchange in which Pak
criticized Brown for making a "business deal with Jeff David" and referring "questions cases to
him. " She asserted "our clients already have own new lawyer why they asking questions to their
case to Jeff. " Instead of denying that the clients had a new attorney, Brown responded: "No
arrangement with Jeff. He would be backup if DN is not available or not interested " Exh.
1573, p. 3 (emphasis added.).) This text was followed by a barrage of text messages from Pak
over the next two months, talking about the problems with various cases, including statute of
limitation problems and 154 cases with serious problems which had been transferred into
Norris's name. Brown's only response was to direct her to transfer the problematic cases back to
him. At no time in this series of text messages over this several month period did Brown express
any discomfort or disagreement with the transfer of cases to Norris, nor did he give Pak any real
guidance about what to do with the SOL problems and other legal problems she was finding.
This series of text messages is strong evidence that Brown agreed that the cases should be
transferred to Norris and that he was providing little to no oversight to Pak, a nonlawyer, about
what to do with the remaining cases or questions that were being raised and problems that were
being uncovered.
Brown also admitted that he entered into an agreement with Norris on November 16,
2020 whereby Brown agreed to accept 80% of all attorney fees received relative to the Androge l
testosterone gel mass tort cases previously handled by Brown's office. (RT 1 /22/25, p. 1I7:10-
1 19: 15 and Exh. I.) He could not recall any conversations with Pak about the percentage chosen
but agrees he voluntarily signed this agreement. Upon further examination at trial, he confessed
that he has no memory of this agreement or the Androgel case. (RT 1/23/25 at p. 38:2-41:6.)
Although he acknowledges his signature on the document, he does not have any memory of

Brown claims it was not until June 2023 that he first became suspicious that Pak was not
working exclusive ly for him and that there was anything amiss with his mass tort practice.2 He
claims he first realized there was something wrong when he sent an email to Pak, asking for an
update on some of their cases. (RT 1/22/25 p. 119: 19 -122:28 and Exh. 1651.) In that email he
asked for client name, case type, when the complaint was filed, summary of claim facts and
when case would be completed and closed from a legal assistant. (Id., and Exh. 1651.) Pak's
response was largely incomprehensible and aggressive, telling him her contract with Brown was
"voided, " but oddly not directly stating that all of the cases had been transferred to Donald
Norris. Around this same time, Brown contacted a former paralegal Lucas Granillo, with whom
he was still in contact, and asked Granillo to "check on the status of a few cases. " Granillo went
on Pacer to investigate some of their federal cases and found that Norris had been substituted
into many cases. Granillo testified that Norris seemed "surprised" by this news. (RT 2/14/25 at
p. 94:1-96:27.)
With respect to the decision to enter the office suite at 3055 Wilshire, Brown appeared to
have little recollection of the decisions leading up to that step. He claims he did not know they
were going to bring a computer expert to copy files or retain a security company to accompany
them. (RT 1/27/25 am, p. 29:24-33:4.) He denies that he or his wife were the decision-maker s
in barring Norris from the offices after October 21, 2023. (Id., at p. 35:24-36:19.) Later in his
testimony, Brown changed his testimony, explaining that he decided to have security accompany
them because he feared there might be violence; and that he went to the office with the intent to
remove Norris from the offices with the use of security. (RT 1/28/25 at p. 68: l 5-25.) Brown
signed the actual agreement with the security company and the computer forensics company that
copied Norris's files. (Exh. 1657 and 1658.)
Testimony of Richard Holstrom
Plaintiffs offered the testimony of forensic accountant Richard Holstrom to quantify his
claimed damages and to provide expert testimony on law firm accounting. (RT 3/5/25, pp. 32-
25.) Holstrom testified that, based on his review of the bank account records, in 2019 and 2020,
Pak and Brown received roughly equal payments from the law firm during those years. (RT
3/7/25, p. 34: 17 -p. 42: 10 Exh. 1697, 1699, 1700.) He further confirmed that the money that wa
paid to purchase leads from the Brown business account appears to have come from money
transferred into the account by Pak and that Brown had full access to these records in 2019 and
2020 (and beyond). (RT 3/7/25, pp. 44-46.) Holstrom also presented lengthy testimony about
the attorney fees Brown should have received from the cases transferred to Norris. The court
does not summarize this testimony because, as discussed further below, the court finds Brown is
not entitled to any portion of these fees.
2 Around the same time, Brown claims he also discovered that the website for the Donald Norris
law firm contained a link or "protected page, " which included information about Baird Brown,
well as Brown's photograph. (Exh. 1558 and 1652.)

28 Testimony of Ann Brown
Plaintiff Ann Brown testified to several key issues in this case. First, she testified that her
husband did not want to retire when he was first diagnosed with Parkinson's in June 2019, nor at
any time thereafter. (RT 3/5/25, p. 160:3-p.161:5.) She acknowledges that her husband had
back surgery at the end of 2019, from which he had a long recovery period. He could not drive
for an extended period. (Id., at p. 161:6-p. 162: 12.) Nonetheless, she claims he never told her
he wanted to retire. (Id.) She admits that from March 2020 until the early part of 2023, he did
not go to work except occasionally on weekends. Nonetheless, she claims he still continued to
work from home and to communicate with Pak on a daily basis and expressed no interest in
retiring. (Id., at p. 162:6-p. 163: 12.) She maintained this position at trial despite the fact that she
also acknowledged that in January 2022 her husband developed Covid, "nearly died, " was placed
on a ventilator and had to be hospitalized for a month, after which he was in inpatient care for a
period of time and then at home receiving therapy. As far as the court can determine, Baird
Brown appears to have been virtually incapacitated due to Covid for at least 4 to 5 months. (Id.,
at p. 164: 10-167: 10.) Mrs. Brown confirmed that during the entire time that he was hospitalized
to her knowledge there was no attorney taking responsibility for any of his cases. (Id., at p. 186.)
Mrs. Brown also claims that she was aware that the Brown firm was purchasing leads in
the amount of $635,000 in June 2019, which she thought was inadvisable. Her husband told her
that it was a good business investment. (Id., at p. 169, ln. 17-170, In. 22.) The court found this
testimony unlikely, given that her testimony was imprecise and she admitted that at this same
time her husband was not telling her the truth about one key issue -that he was under
investigation by the state bar and facing a one-year suspension. (TR 3/13/25, p. 133:8-26.)
Indeed, she only learned about the investigation and his suspension because Pak shared this
informati on with her when Baird was hospitalized with Covid in 2022; Mrs. Brown
acknowledged that because her husband was "embarrassed, " he hid this information from her for
three years. (Id.) She also indicated that she had no knowledge of her husband entering any kind
of relationship with Norris, while it is undisputed from the records that Brown approved the
substitution of Norris onto the Roh case (discussed below) and signed a written agreement to
give him 20% of all of proceeds from the Androgel cases. Apparently, there was a lot of
informati on that Baird did not share with his wife. She also testified that she was aware that her
husband had been retained by the Mick family in 2014, but that her husband told her he was
doing nothing on the case. (3/13/25 RT pp. 125-128.) This further supports the court's
conclusion that Brown knew he needed another attorney to handle cases, the Mick case being
just one of them.
Mrs. Brown also acknowledged what was clear from the other evidence -throughout the
entire period that Baird Brown now claims he was deprived of his case load and deluded about
Norris's involvement, Baird had full access to SugarSync, his office's case management system,
and would have seen that legal work was being performed by Norris. In addition, he had access
to his business and trust accounts and would have seen that he was no longer receiving fees from
most of his cases. Again, this evidence supports a finding that either Brown thought his cases
were being magically (and illegally) prosecuted by his legal assistants, or he knew that Norris
was handling his case load based on their agreement.
Mrs. Brown testified that she believes that as a result of Pak and Norris's conduct, she

Testimony of Carolina Navarro
Mrs. Brown's testimony was contradicted by that of Carolina Navarro, a former client of
Mr. Brown's, who worked for the firm in 2019. Navarro testified that in 2019, she was tasked
with driving Baird Brown to doctor's appointment s, during which he complained to her about
"shakiness. " During this same time, he told her that he was "coming to an end with the law
firm. " (RT 3/7/25. p. 116:17-118:17.) She also recalls three meetings, either with Brown
present or with Brown on the phone, in which his leaving the practice of law was discussed: a
meeting sometime "before summer" of2019; a second meeting over Zoom towards the end of
2019 where the staff was present in Pak's office and Mr. Brown was on the phone and "a lot of
cases were discussed" and a third, in person meeting. (Id., p. 118:27-121:28; p. 139:6-141:9.) It
was at the last meeting that she met Norris for the first time. Navarro places this meeting
sometime in 2020. At this meeting, Brown and Pak introduced Norris to the office staff, telling
them that Norris was going to be working on some of their cases. (Id., at p. 138:8 -p. 139:5.)
She also confirmed that she had a conversation with Mr. Brown and Pak in which she was told
that some of the 3M cases were going to be transferred to Norris and for her for work on those
cases with Norris. (Id., at p. 142:2-148:27.) Although Ms. Navarro's dates appeared confused,
the court found her to be an extremely credible and even guileless witness, who appeared
genuinely to like and care for Mr. Brown and his wife.
Testimony of Michelle Pak
Michelle Pak's testified at length about her dealings with both law firms. She was paid
50% of the firm's profits from the outset of her job with the Brown Law firm, commencing in
200 l until late in the "Covid lock down period. " (RT 1/27 /25, p. 10: 13-11:28; RT 1/22/25, p.
100:1-17; RT 1/22/25, p. 100:18-25.) Pak explained that she oversaw the office and did all of
the marketing for the firm; she was responsible, she claimed, for bringing in all of the clients for
the firm's mass tort practice. (RT 2/7/25, p. 69: 12-70:6.) As part of her agreement with Brown,
she advanced the costs of marketin g and purchasing leads, for which she was reimbursed first
when the firm received money; after that amount was reimbursed, she received a 50% share of
the remaining profits. (Id., at p. 70:3-21.) She denied handling any of the legal work, including
settlements. (Id., at p. 71: ln 8-72: 5.)
Pak testified that sometime in May or June 2019, Brown told her that he had been
diagnosed with Parkinson's and that he was going to be retiring to focus on his health. He
advised her to find a new attorney to take over their office's mass tort practice and to enter into a
new profit-sharing arrangement with that attorney. (RT 1/27/25, p. 50:16-55:20; RT 2/5/25, p.
17: 19-21: 12.) He told her he was very fatigued and needed to engage in many treatments to
address his health condition and so intended to retire. (2/7/25 RT p. 75:17-77:5.) Perhaps
inconsistently, she testified that he appeared very strong and healthy, went to the gym every day
and was still actively managing his case load during this period. (Id., at p. 77: 12 to 78:2.) Luc
Granillo confirmed that in the first few months of 2020, Brown hobbled a pit and his hands

Around this same time, May or June of 2019, Pak claims she told Brown that in light of
his decision to retire, her contractual relationship with him was terminated. Later in her
testimony, she placed this conversation as early as April 2019, explaining that it was
immediatel y after the MRI which diagnosed Brown with Parkinson 's. Even later in her
testimony, she stated that June 2020 was the first time that she told him that their contract was
voided. (RT 2/14/25 RT at p. 21:6 -22:3.) With leading, she then corrected herself again and
said the first time she told Brown their agreement was voided was June 2019. (Id., at p. 22:13-
25.) Then she doubled down and stated that she told him their contract was voided in June 2020.
Despite all this prevaricating, she claims that Brown and she discussed at some uncertain time
that she could continue to work in the office, overseeing the settlement of their cases, handling
the medical liens, and she was told to finish the work, even that which an attorney should do.
She tried to communicate with Brown in the ensuing months about some of the cases as they
wound up, but she asserts he expressed little interest in them, particularly the low value cases.
(Id., at p. 23:3 top. 27:23.)
Pak claims that when Brown told her that he wanted to retire in 2019, he explained that
he wanted to keep only a few of the individual personal injury cases. He informed her he did not
want to keep the mass tort cases because they took two to six years to complete. (RT 2/7/25, p.
80: 10-28.) He also wanted to retain some cases which had "already settled, " like the Androgel
case. (Id.) With respect to the Androgel case, he told Pak because it was nearly completely
settled, he wanted Norris to take it over, for an 80/20 fee split in Brown's favor. (Id., at p. 81: 13-
25.)
Pak testified that although she was aware that Brown was the subject of a state bar
investigation in 2019 (and had hired an attorney to represent him in that matter), she was
shocked to find out in March of 2020 that the bar was going to suspend him. He had not told her
that he might be suspended. (RT 2/7/25 at p. 78:3 -p. 80:9.)
She gave conflicting testimony about when she first met Norris and when they began to
work together. In her deposition, she claimed that she first started working for Norris after
Brown's suspension became effective on April 1, 2020. (RT 1/27/25 p. m., p. 42:8 -44:20.) Yet
she also admitted that she signed a document on July 30,2019, nearly a year earlier, which she
claims Norris drafted, which would have had her receive 90% ofNorris's mass-tort practice. (Id.,
at p. 39: 1 to p. 42: 7, and Exh. 1512.) She further claimed that it was Brown who suggested she
draw up the agreement reflected in Exh. 1512 and 1670, when she and Brown met in Brown's
office in June 2019 to discuss his Parkinson's diagnosis. In this conversation, Pak claims he told
her that she should enter into a profit-sharing arrangement with Norris and even encouraged her
to ask for 90% of the profits. (Id., at p. 50, In. 16-p. 55, In. 20.) She conceded that the 90% spli
of profits she was discussing with Norris was far more lucrative than the 50% share she received
from the Brown firm. (RT 2/14/25 TR, p. 122:20-125:5.)
Although she testified on one day that she first started working with Norris after April 1,
2020, she testified elsewhere that in February 2020, she contacted one of Baird's clients, Hyung
Roh, and told him that his case was going to be transferred to Don Norris and sent him a
Substitution of Attorney form which had been prepared by Brown. She claims that in February

she was still acting as Brown's office manager when she sent the substitution documents to Roh
and explained to him that the case was being transferred to Norris. (Id., at 36, Ins. 16-21.) She
also admitted at trial that she knew the Roh case was a "multimillion " dollar case. (Id., at 40, 18-
21.) She claims she told Roh that the case was being transferred to Norris because of Brown's
suspension and because he intended to retire. (Id., at 31, Ins. 20-26.) She admitted that at the
time she knew that Brown had associated in Brian Panish as co-counsel only a month earlier but
explains that it was her understanding that the Panish firm was only going to help with
settlement, not actual litigation. (Id., at 29, In. 4-p. 30, In. 16; and Exh. 1527.) Realizing her
numerou s inconsistencies, she then testified that Brown discussed with her that he was going to
be suspended before March 2020. (Id., at p. 34, ln. 4-25.) She was impeached with her
deposition testimony where she stated that he did not tell her about the suspension until the end
of March and she did not tell Norris about it until after they received the suspension letter.
(Depo. Transcript, p. 117:10-18; pp.234:5-235:10.)

Norris was aware that Brown's cases were being transferred to him, commencing in the
fust quarter of 2020, although there may have been a few that transferred in December 2019.
Brown never voiced any objection to the transfer and Norris believed that he was fully on board
with the plan to wind down his practice and transfer his cases to Norris. (RT 3/5/25, p. 18:3 -
19:28.) Norris played no role in the transfers, which were handled entirely by Brown's office
staff. He denies directing the process or being involved in the paperwork or interactions with
clients. (id. and RT 3/5/25, pp. 82:24-83:6.) There was no evidence presented by plaintiff to
show that he participated in the process.
Although Norris had wanted to move all of the case files to his own office in downtown
Los Angeles, Pak persuaded Norris to continue to continue to handle the cases out of the Brown
law offices in Korea town. She told Norris that Brown felt more comfortable keeping them in
his own office because they had once been his clients and he wanted Norris to continue to use his
staff to work on those cases. (RT 3/5/25, at p. 59.) Norris never discussed the rent of the Korea
town offices with Brown. Instead, Pak told him that "she was covering it. " He does recall being
asked to pay $15,000 towards the rent at some point by Pak, which he did, but he does not recall
the specifics. (id., at p. 59:26-60:24.) He did not provide any testimony or evidence to
establish that he paid any other office expenses, rent, or staff costs for the Wilshire Avenue
offices during the period in question (April 2020 to October 21, 2023).
Norris confirmed that Brown represented Norris and Brown in malpractice litigation
brought against both of them by an heir to one of their clients, known as the "Mick case. "
(3/5/25 pp. 21:8.-p. 22: 13.) Throughout his representation of Norris on that case, Brown never
mentioned that he believed he should have been paid by Norris for any of the cases Norris had
been handling. (id.)
Norris was not present when the Browns and their attorneys went to the offices on
Wilshire on October 21, 2023, and ejected Pak and Norris. He met with the Whites a few days
afterwards at Starbucks. At that meeting, the Whites accused Norris of having stolen cases from
Brown, which Norris denied; he explained to the Whites that the cases had been transferred to
him by Brown. Norris told the Whites that there were many files in the office belonging to his
clients -clients who had never been represented by the Brown law firm -to which he needed
access. The Whites agreed that Norris could go with them to the suite to identify those files,
which they did that same day, but Norris claims he was only provided 45 minutes to go through, The court observes that both firm's agreements with Pak were unsavory and may have
bordered on unethical. Because both firms appeared to employ this same unusual business
model of paying for leads to solicit clients and then at times appearing to pay Pak, a non-lawyer,
a percentage of fees recovered, neither complained about the other's practices or presented law
or argument about these practices. Accordingly, the court does not express any opinion or
findings about the legality or ethics of these practices, beyond observing that both lawyers seem
to have used poor judgment and disregard of ethical constrictions in their involvement with Pak.
